awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Linking Pharmacokinetics to Epidemiological Models of Vector-Borne Diseases and Drug Resistance Prevention
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to develop mathematical tools to improve understanding of how the behavior of drugs within the body, and their effects on pathogens, influence the spread of drug-resistant disease. Drugs that target microbes (antimicrobials) have saved millions of lives. But, because microbes evolve, over time antimicrobials reduce the population of pathogens that succumb to drugs and leave behind those that do not - a process called selection. Consequently, unbridled use of antimicrobials threatens their long-term efficacy - a concern since the discovery of penicillin in 1928. Today, drug resistance is recognized as a serious problem requiring urgent attention. Differential equations can describe mechanisms that drive changes in living systems; control theory can generate the best strategies to use these mechanisms to achieve a desired goal. These tools will help guide drug development and dosing protocols that balance the immediate benefits of administering antimicrobials with the long-term selection pressure imposed by these drugs. A mathematical framework that is adaptable to different disease systems could inform strategies to reduce the threat of resistant pathogens to global health and the attendant cost to society. Furthermore, this project will provide graduate students at Howard, Texas Tech, Lehigh, and the University of Kentucky, with the opportunity to intern at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, fostering connections outside of academia.  University of Kentucky students will also assist the lead investigator in mentoring high school students through a pilot Saturday Morning Math program that will provide hands-on experience with coding, modeling, and visualization of scientific results.

The investigators aim to construct a general mathematical framework, with vector-borne disease serving as a benchmark example, and build the tools needed to bridge the gap between within-host PK/PD (pharmacokinetics/pharmacodynamics) and population-level epidemiology, so that others may readily adapt the framework to their own studies of competing pathogens. The investigators will approach the problem of linking the fast dynamics of PK/PD to the comparatively slow population-level dynamics by introducing serial compartments in a system of nonlinear ordinary differential equations representing the progression of individuals through stages of treatment characterized by different drug concentrations and different durations. A stochastic sub-model is proposed to parameterize one of the functions that links within-host PK/PD to the population-level dynamics.  The proposed research is important because, to date, no general methods exist to analyze a staged-progression model where the stages have different durations. Such a model could provide results and insights that significantly improve the protocols for drug interventions in a way that mitigates the selection pressure leading to drug resistance. For example, it is unknown how the likely existence of backward bifurcation and the staged-progression approach with heterogeneous stages will interact and influence optimal treatment policy. Furthermore, the proposed parameter estimation, uncertainty, and identifiability analyses will likely lead to challenging mathematical and statistical problems requiring advances of existing methodologies.  

This project is funded by the Division of Mathematical Sciences Mathematical Biology Program and Division of Human Resource Development HBCU-UP.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
(A) Key publication outcomes: 

Paper in Letters in Biomath-Outcome-Spline methodology linked temperature-dependent mosquito-demographic and malaria parasite traits to regional temperature data, creating seasonal trait/parameter profiles corresponding to recorded average monthly temperatures of the studied locality, without forcing a sinusoidal fit to the data. Temperatures are integrated  by mapping the temperature-dependent mosquito traits to time-varying parameters, yielding temperature-to-time varying parameters embedded into a model developed to understand malaria transmission with drug treatment.  Model simulations capture the effects of temperature fluctuations and shifts in average monthly temperatures within -2o-2oC on monthly entomological inoculation rates (mEIR) and malaria infections over three years in the studied regions. This approach of mapping temperature-dependent traits/parameters to creat time-varying regional temperature-linked traits/parameters, using it to inform region-specific malaria disease burdens is forward thinking and innovative.  It allowed for the investigation of small temperature shifts on malaria burdens.

Paper in MATCOM-Highlights how human consciousness can be ignited via educational campaigns to help eliminate temporal mosquito breeding sites (aquatic habitats), which would be crucial in the fight against malaria, especially in areas where permanent breeding sites are scarce. The significance is that the work introduces a topic needing further research.

Paper in Math Biosci-Mosquitoes that failed to feed on their first attempt, but live to try again (waiting-class mosquitoes), eventually succeeding, are important players in understanding shifts in mosquito abundance, hence malaria dynamics. Model results illustrate that multiple probing success positively enhance mosquito survival/abundance, with waiting class mosquitoes reducing extinction chances and affecting oscillation frequency. Additionally, the computed basic offspring number is affected by the interpretation of new births and transitions. These results, with some reported for the first time, are important: disrupt gonotrophic cycle flow path by providing a bypass state, waiting class mosquitoes, where mosquitoes can detour into. Scenarios exists were these waiting class mosquitoes become a pathway to recovery for the mosquito population when the numbers are small. Results usefulness/impact is the illustration that waiting class mosquitoes contribute positively to sustaining mosquito populations,

Paper in J Dyn Diff Equation-Improves past epidemiological models for mosquito-borne diseases that assume, for analysis simplification, exponentially distributed residence times in disease stages. Model results based on the non-exponential distributions are expected to be more reliable than models that assume simple but unrealistic assumptions such as exponentially distributed infection and treated stages. With non-exponentially distributed infection and treated stages, the model accounts for differential immune effects in infected and treated humans, as well as the time when a symptomatic infected human commences treatment, thus capturing the biological processes and characteristics about malaria disease progression that are shown in data. Hence, the model is more realistic. In addition, it provides a way to link disease transmission dynamics to drug effects on parasitemia and parasite load within a human host and onset of treatment.

Paper in J Theor Biol., 2021-Model results highlight how malaria can be controlled using transmission blocking vaccines (TBV) and transmission blocking drugs (TBD). TBVs and TBDs against malaria are intended for use to in humans to trigger an immune response in a TBV vaccinated human or one who took the drug. The triggered immune antibodies, when ingested by a blood feeding mosquito, can inhibit the developmental stages of the within-mosquito parasite forms. Exploiting this fact that ingested human antibodies that can inhibit fertilization between male and female gametes in mosquitoes provide a malaria control medthod via TBVs and TBDs.

Paper in The Lancet Infectious Diseases, 21, 5–6-Had potential to inform public policy on malaria control during the COVID-19 pandemic.

(B.) Student Training Outcomes:

Undergraduates: (I)  Grant Funded Students- (1) Benjamin Brindle, Grad 2021, B.S. Math, pursuing a PhD in Applied Math, Johns Hopkins University. (2) Samantha Roth, Grad 2018, BS Statistics,  pursuing a PhD in Statistics, Penn State. (3) Alexander Diefes (transferred to Duke), looking towards grad school. 

(II) Other student cohort in my team, not directly funded by grant. (1) Anna Thomas, B.S. Math 2021, pursuing her PhD in Applied Mathematics, University of Pittsburgh, (2) Xiangyi Tao, BS Math, 2021, Pursued a Masters in Applied Mathematics at New York University (NYU).

(II) Graduate students:

3 MS Graduates: Fru & Njongwe (both MS Math, 12/2019); Jumbam (MS Math, 12/2020),  from the University of Buea. James is enrolled in the PhD program in math and has Outcome: 1 Publication.

1 PhD Graduate: Bime Markdonal, Univ of Buea, Cameroon, defended PhD dissertation, 12/2022.

2 Mathematics PhD candidates: Girma Zelleke and George Nforba,  University of Buea, Cameroon, candidates progressing. PI is co-supervising their PhD dissertations.

(C.)  Supported Mathematics in Developing Countries through co-supervision of Masters theses and PhD Dissertations in Cameroon, a developing country.

Outcome: Invited to present on this at the Joint Mathematics Meeting (JMM), 01/6-9, 2021. Title: Supporting Mathematics in Developing Countries: Case of Collaboration with Dr Ngwa and the University of Buea, Cameroon. 

Invited to Join MAA Focus Editorial Board.
